Licensing R Colin Fay 2019-03-02 Chapter 1 Licensing R 1.1 Disclaimer This book is by no mean a legal book and should not be used as such. This book aims at helping you decipher the complexity of open source licenses, but if you have legal concerns and questions about open source licenses, please refer to a professional lawyer. 1.2 What is this book about This book aims at two things: Documenting the current state of licensing in the R world Summarize and explain technical terms specific to open source license.

Chapter 2 Introduction 2.1 Diving into the CRAN & BioConductor database library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.1.0 ✔ purrr 0.3.0 ## ✔ tibble 2.0.1 ✔ dplyr 0.8.0.1 ## ✔ tidyr 0.8.2 ✔ stringr 1.3.1 ## ✔ readr 1.3.1 ✔ forcats 0.3.0 ## ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() Getting all the packages # Done on Sys.time() ## [1] "2019-03-02 19:41:52 CET" # Getting the DB cran_db <- tools::CRAN_package_db() %>% thinkr::clean_names() bioc_db <- read.dcf(url("https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/src/contrib/PACKAGES")) %>% as.data.frame() %>% thinkr::clean_names() cran_small <- cran_db %>% select(package, contains("license")) %>% mutate(src = "cran") bioc_small <- bioc_db %>% select(package, contains("license")) %>% mutate(src = "bioc") db <- rbind(cran_small, bioc_small) How many different licenses? db %>% distinct(license) %>% count() ## # A tibble: 1 x 1 ## n ## <int> ## 1 172 Counting the number of package with a licence file: db$has_file_licence <- str_detect(db$license, "file") # How many have a li db %>% count(has_file_licence) ## # A tibble: 3 x 2 ## has_file_licence n ## <lgl> <int> ## 1 FALSE 13008 ## 2 TRUE 2419 ## 3 NA 2 Counting the license_is_foss: # Not that much information db %>% count(license_is_foss) ## # A tibble: 3 x 2 ## license_is_foss n ## <chr> <int> ## 1 <NA> 15417 ## 2 no 1 ## 3 yes 11 db %>% filter(license_is_foss == "no") ## package license license_is_foss ## 1 MotifDb Artistic-2.0 | file LICENSE no ## license_restricts_use src has_file_licence ## 1 yes bioc TRUE How many package have a license with restrictive use? db %>% count(license_restricts_use) ## # A tibble: 3 x 2 ## license_restricts_use n ## <chr> <int> ## 1 <NA> 15401 ## 2 no 10 ## 3 yes 18 db %>% filter(license_restricts_use == "yes") %>% select(package, license) ## package license ## 1 akima ACM | file LICENSE ## 2 alphahull file LICENSE ## 3 asypow ACM | file LICENSE ## 4 gpclib file LICENSE ## 5 momr Artistic-2.0 ## 6 PredictiveRegression file LICENSE ## 7 regtest file LICENSE ## 8 rindex file LICENSE ## 9 rngwell19937 file LICENSE ## 10 sfdct CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 ## 11 sigQC file LICENSE ## 12 tripack ACM | file LICENSE ## 13 CNEr GPL-2 | file LICENSE ## 14 genArise file LICENSE ## 15 GraphAlignment file LICENSE ## 16 MotifDb Artistic-2.0 | file LICENSE ## 17 RankProd file LICENSE ## 18 SPIA file LICENSE db %>% filter(license_restricts_use == "yes") %>% count(license, sort = TRUE) ## # A tibble: 6 x 2 ## license n ## <chr> <int> ## 1 file LICENSE 11 ## 2 ACM | file LICENSE 3 ## 3 Artistic-2.0 1 ## 4 Artistic-2.0 | file LICENSE 1 ## 5 CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 1 ## 6 GPL-2 | file LICENSE 1 Cleaning the license name because to get a more global idea cleaner <- compose( # Removing the file licence elements ~ gsub("filelicense", "", .x), ~ gsub("filelicence", "", .x), # Removing empty spaces ~ gsub(" ", "", .x), # Removing all non-alpha numeric character proustr::pr_keep_only_alnum, # Removing the .0 at the end of numbers ~ gsub("\\.0", "", .x), tolower ) db <- db %>% mutate(clean_license = cleaner(license)) db %>% count(clean_license, sort = TRUE) ## # A tibble: 96 x 2 ## clean_license n ## <chr> <int> ## 1 gpl2 7206 ## 2 gpl3 3696 ## 3 mit 1644 ## 4 gpl 547 ## 5 artistic2 490 ## 6 gpl2gpl3 302 ## 7 lgpl3 196 ## 8 apachelicense2 184 ## 9 cc0 133 ## 10 bsd3clause 126 ## # … with 86 more rows How many GPL related licenses? # How many GPL based licenses ? n_gpl <- str_detect(db$clean_license, "gpl") %>% sum(na.rm = TRUE) n_gpl ## [1] 12393 (n_gpl / nrow(db)) * 100 ## [1] 80.32277 How may licenses are used just once? db %>% count(clean_license) %>% filter(n == 1) ## # A tibble: 31 x 2 ## clean_license n ## <chr> <int> ## 1 apachelicenseversion2 1 ## 2 artistic2gpl2 1 ## 3 ccbysa2 1 ## 4 cecill2gpl2 1 ## 5 cpl 1 ## 6 cpl1 1 ## 7 eupl11 1 ## 8 freebsdgpl2 1 ## 9 gpl1 1 ## 10 gpl210 1 ## # … with 21 more rows What are the 10 most frequent licenses? db %>% count(clean_license, sort = TRUE) %>% top_n(10) ## Selecting by n ## # A tibble: 10 x 2 ## clean_license n ## <chr> <int> ## 1 gpl2 7206 ## 2 gpl3 3696 ## 3 mit 1644 ## 4 gpl 547 ## 5 artistic2 490 ## 6 gpl2gpl3 302 ## 7 lgpl3 196 ## 8 apachelicense2 184 ## 9 cc0 133 ## 10 bsd3clause 126 db %>% count(clean_license, sort = TRUE) %>% top_n(10) %>% ggplot(aes(reorder(clean_license, n), n )) + geom_col() + coord_flip() + labs( title = "10 most used licenses on the CRAN / Bioconductor", substile = glue::glue("Made on the {Sys.Date()}"), x = "License", y = "Volume" ) + theme_minimal() ## Selecting by n

Chapter 3 What is a license (and why you should care) 3.1 Definition 3.2 Classification 3.3 Implication 3.4 License compatibility

Chapter 3 What is a license (and why you should care) Intro: why is license important? Potential pitfalls: commercial reuse, license incompatibility, potential issues with changing licenses. Exemples : Bootstrap: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/issues/2054) {covr}: https://github.com/ropensci/unconf17/issues/32 But first, some definitions. 3.1 Definition 3.1.1 License Defining what is a license. 3.1.2 Distribute What does “distributing a software” means? => Code you bundle (distribute) VS code you depend on. 3.1.3 Free software Defining what is a free software (free beer vs free speech, https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/free-sw.en.html ) 3.1.4 Copyleft https://www.gnu.org/licenses/licenses.en.html 3.2 Classification Find a good way to classify licenses, maybe inspired by: https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.en.html#Introduction 3.3 Implication What are the implications of choosing a license? 3.4 License compatibility Not all licenses are compatible, see for example Apache & GPL which have a one way compatibility: http://www.apache.org/licenses/GPL-compatibility.html

Chapter 5 Licensing R code Checklist about what to think about when defining your R code license. 5.1 R-package 5.1.1 Code 5.1.1.1 Defining your code reusability Reminder here about how the license you choose impact the way people can reuse your code. 5.1.1.2 Contribution Discussion here about contribution to your package. -asking people to sign a CLA - https://github.com/ropensci/unconf17/issues/32#issuecomment-294038058 implication for changing license ({covr} example) 5.1.2 Dependancies License compatibility questions when it comes to using dependencies in a package. 5.1.3 Data Package How to license a data package? https://github.com/ropensci/unconf17/issues/61 https://github.com/ropenscilabs/data-packages Examples: https://github.com/igraph/igraphdata : {igraphdata} has a file LICENSE with each licenses listed : https://github.com/igraph/igraphdata/blob/master/LICENSE 5.1.4 Library wrappers 5.1.4.1 Including non R code (JavaScript, C++, CSS…) How should a code wrapper be licensed? Exemple: include others as role="ctb" with LICENSE.note: see for example {leaflet} https://github.com/rstudio/leaflet / https://github.com/rstudio/crosstalk 5.2 Documentation 5.2.1 Software documentation Discussion about code documentation (vignette, bookdown, blog articles…) 5.2.2 Publication Overview of license requirements (if any) for publication in journals. Example: JSS “Code needs to include the GNU General Public Licence (GPL), versions GPL-2 or GPL-3, or a GPL-compatible license for publication in JSS.” https://www.jstatsoft.org/pages/view/authors
